history.content: As with any CS class that has a public website, read the notes from the previous semester to get a head start.

children.subject: Awesome, thank you for the info!

The only part of 61C we require for 161 is C memory management and manipulating the stack in RISC-V (specifically for function calls). We also hold 61C review sessions at the beginning of the semester to brush up on everything.

source: 161 TA
New anon here. Do you think taking cs161 would be wise if I plan to take cs162 and cs170?
(og anon) thanks for the advice and computerphile recommendation!

@new anon: don't recommend those three together. I think 162 and 170 are the hardest general CS courses we offer. For reference I am taking 162 + crypto (which is like 170 but harder, but less work) and a third time-consuming class + a breadth and it's hell. Also, 162 now has a final (so 3 heavy material finals), and whenever you have 162 + 161 projects due at the same time + a 170 pset it will be very hard to do. I think you can take a combination of 2 of any of those and be safe if you have good work ethic (this is especially true for 162 + 170, as 161 + 170 and 161 + 162 should be easier to handle). But the three in combination would be hard to handle even if you generally outperform your peers just because you are being tested on the two extremes (math and systems) at the same time plus 161 is kind of it's own thing (so there will be a very small overlap between 161, 162 and 170) and there's also a bunch of work, especially for 162 and 170

Hi OP, I didn't do that well on 70 or 61c and I still managed to do well in 161. The only things that you must be familiar of 61c content is understanding the memory layout, registers, how the stack grows, and how to read RISC V code. Aside from this you should be fine. I don't remember anything from 70 being thoroughly emphasized in the course. I recommend watching the Computerphile's videos on crypto and reading notes about Integrity, Auth and Encryption if you want a head start
(op) I was planning to take it since it seems very relevant to swe so that's interesting. Doubt I can get into 162 next semester, any other swe relevant courses you would recommend instead?

cs186 is a relevant swe class IF you know you will work as database software developer. I think at this point it will depend on what you intentions are. Take for example cs164 compilers, it a very relevant swe class but is focused. If you plan to work as a "generalist swe" then you want to make sure of taking the classes that you know will be possibly useful for you career goals. In my case, I am more of an appdev/ML/networks so cs189, cs161, cs189, cs182, d100 will be the best bet for me. cs169 software engineering is a good class regardless of your focus but won't be offered this spring. If you feel you have a great curiosity for cs186 just take it, but again, my personal opinion plus some friends' agree that we did not gain a particular useful skill other than the experience of dealing with large amount of code. Take in mind that all homework are individual, the piazza support is not great and the OH are very... VERY impacted so if you run into problems or get stuck you won't have a fun time.

Just a quick note on cs186: if you plan to take this class because some student say is the easiest upper div that a complete lie. cs186 is at pair with classes such as cs61b. We only have 5 HW aka projects but the amount of code you have to deal with can only be surpassed by few upper divs like cs162 and the compiler class. To be honest with you, I don't feel cs186 gave me something useful for industry as a software developer (unless, of course, you plant to work as core database developer at Oracle, Microsoft, etc) It is good in the sense that you learn about the tradeoffs and you can think a bit better on how to design schemas and how to write efficient queries having in mind how the guts of a DB works. If I could have the option to retake a different class instead of cs186 I would do it without doubt. Again, this is just my take.

history.content: As per title, I haven't done well in 61c or 70 this semester due to personal health issues and I'm looking for advice for over the break regarding how to prepare for 161 (and 186). Obviously the RSA and modular arithmetic stuff will be applicable from 70 and the C memory related stuff from 61c should be reviewed (I think). Anything else I should focus on? Other material sources? Advice for 186? Any other specific advice would be very appreciated. Thanks in advance.
history.subject: Did Not Do Well In 61C/70, How To Prepare For 161
